name: TheAtlantic
text: Some experts have reservations about rapid antigen tests—and the White House's cavalier attitude toward these tests has realized those fears, @alexismadrigal and @yayitsrob write: https://t.co/VdoT5hEGmn

name: TheAtlantic
text: "The evidence is pointing in one direction. Schools do not, in fact, appear to be a major spreader of COVID-19," @ProfEmilyOster writes: https://t.co/kmE7rlFr5W

name: TheAtlantic
text: Trump keeps looking for a silver bullet to end the pandemic. Monoclonal antibodies might be promising, but they are still far from a “cure.” @sarahzhang reports: https://t.co/UiyKLshdlL

name: TheAtlantic
text: The experts recanted their interviews. Fact-checkers debunked it. So why do so many people think that masks can make you sick? @olgakhazan investigates: https://t.co/lA4AbSgN2J

name: TheAtlantic
text: "When uncertainty rages, human nature will lead many people to seek a more stable reality by wrapping themselves in an ever-tighter cloak of political, religious, or racial identities," @intelwire writes: https://t.co/kGxhdjJurk

name: TheAtlantic
text: He boiled strings, cut vibrato bars in half, put the head of one guitar on the body of another—and created a sound that changed rock forever. James Parker remembers Eddie Van Halen: https://t.co/Cgp4oJJXEf

name: TheAtlantic
text: He boiled strings, cut vibrato bars in half, put the head of one guitar on the body of another—and created a sound that changed rock forever. James Parker remembers Eddie Van Halen: https://t.co/ssp3d0m3gc

name: TheAtlantic
text: Books by Claude McKay, Gayl Jones, Kuniko Tsurita, and more in this week's #TheAtlanticBooksBriefing. From @cray_kate: https://t.co/vVCpsHXmSK

name: TheAtlantic
text: The news cycle churns apace. Stay informed, but remember to take breaks. Here's a non-newsy reading list from our editors, in the latest Atlantic Daily by @mimbsy: https://t.co/XHq72JDquh

name: TheAtlantic
text: The poet Louise Glück, who won the Nobel Prize in Literature this week, examines our compulsion to tell the same stories again and again. In the face of destruction, she asks, how can belief in new beginnings possibly still exist? Walt Hunter writes: https://t.co/FjyUfZHQsL

name: TheAtlantic
text: Photos of the Week: A Swiss Guard ceremony in the Vatican, a bear rescue in California, wildfires in Paraguay, pet blessings in the Philippines, and more—via @TheAtlPhoto: https://t.co/8jVqTYT6gp

name: TheAtlantic
text: Photos of the Week: A Swiss Guard ceremony in the Vatican, a bear rescue in California, wildfires in Paraguay, pet blessings in the Philippines, and more—via @TheAtlPhoto: https://t.co/98KCXkibmC

name: TheAtlantic
text: "The very idea of precedent is being politicized in service of the further politicization of the Supreme Court," Jane Chong writes: https://t.co/pe0EZFKLyg

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Under America's reigning ideology, public infrastructure like this is seen as costly, inefficient, outdated, and low-quality, while private alternatives are valorized as more dynamic, efficient, and modern," @ksabeelrahman writes: https://t.co/Shu7QF6mSN
